# Documentation Structure Overview

This document provides an overview of the CSV Cleaner documentation structure and guidelines for maintaining it.

## 📁 Directory Structure

```
docs/
├── README.md                           # Main documentation index
├── DOCUMENTATION_STRUCTURE.md          # This file
├── getting-started/                    # New user onboarding
│   ├── quick-start.md                  # Quick start guide
│   ├── installation.md                 # Installation instructions
│   └── first-steps.md                  # First steps tutorial
├── user-guides/                        # User documentation
│   ├── user-manual.md                  # Complete user manual
│   ├── ai-features.md                  # AI features guide
│   ├── cli-reference.md                # CLI command reference
│   └── configuration.md                # Configuration guide
├── technical/                          # Technical documentation
│   ├── architecture.md                 # System architecture
│   ├── api-reference.md                # API documentation (planned)
│   ├── performance.md                  # Performance guide (planned)
│   └── security.md                     # Security guide (planned)
├── tutorials/                          # Tutorials and examples
│   ├── basic-tutorials.md              # Basic tutorials
│   ├── advanced-tutorials.md           # Advanced tutorials (planned)
│   ├── ai-tutorials.md                 # AI-focused tutorials (planned)
│   └── real-world-examples.md          # Real-world examples (planned)
├── development/                        # Developer documentation
│   ├── developer-guide.md              # Developer guide (planned)
│   ├── testing.md                      # Testing guide (planned)
│   ├── contributing.md                 # Contributing guidelines (planned)
│   └── release-process.md              # Release process (planned)
├── reference/                          # Reference materials
│   ├── faq.md                          # Frequently asked questions
│   ├── troubleshooting.md              # Troubleshooting guide
│   └── glossary.md                     # Terms and definitions (planned)
└── internal/                           # Internal documentation
    ├── prd.md                          # Product requirements
    ├── tech.md                         # Technical specifications
    ├── plan.md                         # Development plan
    ├── monetization.md                 # Monetization strategy
    ├── developer-onboarding.md         # Developer onboarding
    └── ai-logging.md                   # AI logging documentation
```

## 📋 Documentation Categories

### 1. Getting Started
**Audience**: New users, first-time installers
**Purpose**: Get users up and running quickly
**Content**:
- Installation instructions
- Quick start guide
- First steps tutorial
- Basic setup

### 2. User Guides
**Audience**: End users, data analysts, data scientists
**Purpose**: Comprehensive usage documentation
**Content**:
- Complete user manual
- AI features guide
- CLI reference
- Configuration guide

### 3. Technical Documentation
**Audience**: Developers, system administrators, technical users
**Purpose**: Deep technical understanding
**Content**:
- System architecture
- API reference
- Performance optimization
- Security considerations

### 4. Tutorials
**Audience**: Users learning specific features
**Purpose**: Hands-on learning and examples
**Content**:
- Step-by-step tutorials
- Real-world examples
- Best practices
- Common use cases

### 5. Development
**Audience**: Contributors, developers
**Purpose**: Development and contribution guidance
**Content**:
- Developer guide
- Testing procedures
- Contributing guidelines
- Release process

### 6. Reference
**Audience**: All users
**Purpose**: Quick reference and problem solving
**Content**:
- FAQ
- Troubleshooting
- Glossary
- Quick reference

## 📝 Documentation Standards

### File Naming
- Use kebab-case for file names
- Use descriptive, clear names
- Include category prefix when helpful

### Content Structure
- Start with a clear title and description
- Use consistent heading hierarchy (H1, H2, H3)
- Include table of contents for long documents
- End with next steps and related links

### Writing Style
- Use clear, concise language
- Write for the target audience
- Include code examples where appropriate
- Use consistent terminology

### Code Examples
- Use syntax highlighting
- Include comments for clarity
- Provide complete, runnable examples
- Show expected output

### Links and References
- Use relative links within the docs
- Link to related documentation
- Include external references when appropriate
- Keep links up to date

## 🔄 Maintenance Guidelines

### Regular Updates
- Review and update documentation monthly
- Update with each new release
- Fix broken links and outdated information
- Add new content for new features

### Version Control
- Keep documentation in version control
- Use meaningful commit messages
- Review documentation changes in PRs
- Tag documentation with release versions

### Quality Assurance
- Test all code examples
- Verify all links work
- Check for consistency across documents
- Review for clarity and completeness

### User Feedback
- Collect feedback on documentation
- Address common questions in FAQ
- Update based on user confusion
- Monitor documentation usage

## 📊 Documentation Status Tracking

### Status Indicators
- ✅ Complete - Fully documented and up to date
- 🔄 In Progress - Being written or updated
- ⏳ Planned - Planned but not started
- ❌ Not Started - Not yet planned

### Priority Levels
- **High**: Core functionality, installation, quick start
- **Medium**: Advanced features, tutorials, reference
- **Low**: Developer docs, internal docs

## 🎯 Documentation Goals

### User Experience
- Help users get started quickly
- Provide comprehensive coverage
- Make information easy to find
- Support different learning styles

### Content Quality
- Accurate and up-to-date information
- Clear and concise writing
- Useful examples and tutorials
- Consistent formatting and style

### Accessibility
- Clear navigation structure
- Searchable content
- Multiple formats when possible
- Mobile-friendly design

## 🔧 Documentation Tools

### Writing Tools
- Markdown for content
- Git for version control
- GitHub for collaboration
- Automated link checking

### Publishing Tools
- GitHub Pages for hosting
- Automated builds for consistency
- Search functionality
- Analytics for usage tracking

## 📈 Metrics and Analytics

### Usage Metrics
- Page views and time on page
- Search queries and results
- User feedback and ratings
- Common support questions

### Quality Metrics
- Broken link reports
- Outdated content identification
- User satisfaction surveys
- Documentation completion rates

## 🚀 Future Enhancements

### Planned Improvements
- Interactive tutorials
- Video content
- Multi-language support
- Advanced search functionality
- Documentation API

### User Experience
- Better navigation
- Improved search
- Mobile optimization
- Accessibility improvements

## 📞 Documentation Team

### Responsibilities
- **Technical Writers**: Create and maintain content
- **Developers**: Review technical accuracy
- **Product Team**: Ensure feature coverage
- **Community**: Provide feedback and contributions

### Collaboration
- Regular documentation reviews
- Cross-team communication
- User feedback integration
- Continuous improvement process

---

*This structure should be reviewed and updated regularly to ensure it meets the needs of users and maintainers.*
